Definition: If you find that the input comment has pornographic materials and activities that offend the public's sense of decency, then classify it as obscene else classify it as non-obscene.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Cataluna's a butt kicker, but she kicks the wrong butts.
Positive Examples.explanation: This is obscenity because it hints on sexual content that is offensive to the public sense of decency.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Guess Barron needs to babysit the dummy and supervise his tweets.
Positive Examples.explanation: This is unrelated to pornography or obscenity.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: Shut up nerd. You try too hard.
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment might be considered toxic but is not obscene.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: Sailors found whores and coke.I'm shocked!
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment should be considered obscene because it contains explicit language of obscenity.

Comment: From very young ages, my 4 kids had first hand visuals of the mortality and devastating trauma caused by guns on game animals. The cute bunny, deer, bear, etc. laying lifeless with a bloody hole in it. And it didn't get up to star in the next movie. Still, to the chagrin of my peers, I never let them point toy guns (or even their fingers) at a human and say "POW!" No squirt gun fights, playing 'Army', 'Cops and Robbers', 'Cowboys and Indians' or Grand Theft Auto type video games (These came out later and as "adults" they played them anyway...). And I screened (to the best of my ability) their intake of movies and TV. Perhaps I was viewed as a hard ass, but, I know first hand that it sucks to be shot. Yet, guns have always been an important tool in my life and I'm not one to throw out a hammer over a black thumbnail. I've kept them handy and I've kept them loaded. If you haven't taken the time to discipline your children before getting a gun, maybe you should get a baseball bat instead.

Comment: What did a semen-stained blue dress from the Oval Office have to do with a land deal in Arkansas? After a couple of years of digging, that's all a partisan prosecutor could find against Bill Clinton. 
There's nothing unconstitutional about a prosecutor working an investigation finding evidence of other, related or even unrelated crimes. And of course, it's constitutional to pursue those other crimes. 
Watergate started as the investigation of a burglary and led to related crimes that brought Nixon down. 
Say a judge signs a search warrant based on evidence of an illegal poker game in Joe's basement. The cops come in and find they're not gambling, but there is an ounce of cocaine on the card table. Do they walk out and say: "Darn, too bad the warrant's for illegal gambling. Now we can't make a case for the cocaine."
Same as a prosecutor investigating MAFIA underlings to build a RICO case against the mob boss. She may use a drug case as a means of gaining cooperation.

Comment: No one knows how to gauge te outcome based on the ranked ballot.  But isn't the challenge greater than that?   
Each EDA counts as 100 points and the first candidate to get 16901 points, or more, is the winner.  This means that EDA's with a small number of members carry a lot of weight.  If one candidate has 28% support concentrated in many EDA's with few members, that candidate ha a much better chance than another candidate with 35% support concentrated in a few ridings in the GTA.
This is the same approach the Liberals used to choose Justin Trudeau.  Apparently, he had broad support getting over 80% of the points on the first round.  This time around, it seems like a real crap shoot.

Comment: "I recall in the Sixties ..."  which means, Andrew, you probably remember a time when "women professionals" was an oxymoron.  Me, too...and I distinctly recall the first female announcer and first female newscaster hired by the station in the mid-1970s.   See?  Definite progress, no?

Broadcasting? A profession? "Not the same," doctors, dentists and lawyers might sniff.  Well, many of us did consider it so.  An 8-hour day?  Maybe the morning show guy (who got up at 4:45 to be on the air at 6.) Even he did Saturday remotes.  After a five-day week, I'd roll in for 3-4 hours on a Saturday morning, too, to learn more about my craft from a Vancouver writer who came in part-time.  Man, did I learn.  No extra dough, either.  Just...priceless lessons.  Stayed until 6:30 many nights. The production studios were empty and I could record, edit, play around, discover what was possible... 

Maybe there was one difference from, say, the legal firm.  I had FUN, every single damn day.

Comment: Seven year old Mohamed arrived at his classroom on the first day of school.
“What’s your name?”, asked the teacher.
“Mohammad,” he replied.
“You’re in Ireland now,” replied the teacher, “So from now on you will be known as Mike.”
Mohammad returned home after school.
“How was your day, Mohammad?”, his mother asked.
“My name is not Mohammad. I’m in Ireland and now my name is Mike.
“Are you ashamed of your name? Are you trying to dishonor your parents, your heritage, your religion? Shame on you!”
And his mother beat the shit out of him. Then she called his father, who beat the shit out of him again.
The next day Mohammad returned to school. The teacher saw all of his fresh bruises.
“What happened to you, Mike?”, she asked.
“Well, shortly after becoming an Irishman, I was attacked by two fucking Muslims.”

Comment: Who gives a crap where the word originated. I spoke about definition, not etymology. 

It's utterly irrelevant where it originated or what it meant when it was created. What matters is what it means today, what people understand when they hear it. Not what it meant once upon a time.

The word "proves"used to mean "to test and show to be false", giving English the expression "the exception that proves the rule" - which literally meant "the exception that shows the rule isn't actually a rule and is not really true".

Over time "proves" lost the meaning of "to show the falsehood of" and only the meaning of "to show it's true" remained, and the proverb survives even though it's modern day meaning makes no sense. It's a kind of bizarre claim that the the rule is true BECAUSE there are exceptions to it.

Words change their meanings over time - and if you don't know the current meaning, you cannot communicate honestly, logically or usefully.

Comment: Another example of how the Oahu centric political machine treats the outer islands. It's more than a shame when our politicians put the health and safety of others at risk when it is not politically expedient to their own interests. This kind of what matters to Honolulu and screw the rest of you mentality exposes a flaw in the majority take all system we rely upon here. 

A system that is bias to Oahu at the expense of all the outer islands suggests in the long run some amount of autonomy must be sought. If Oahu can not care for the outer islands, it is long overdue for the outer islands to be granted the right, and share of state funds, to care for themselves.

We have seen this inequity played out time and time again. From our schools to our infrastructure needs. Our healthcare facilities lack, our environmental concerns are not protected, we are not protected from invasive species, but damn Oahu gets its rail. At some point there's got to be a reckoning.

Comment: Having lived in both Canada and the USA, I can say from personal experience that Canada is a much less racially polarized society than the USA is.  That said, I really find most of the comments here (even most of the "highly rated" ones) to completely miss the point about what constitutes white privilege.  While in a minor sense, the example used in the article (the grocery store) can exhibit privilege, that is not the issue.

The issue, at least in America, is that (a) black students in schools are targeted for disciplinary actions, leading to arrests, in situations where the same behavior by white students is overlooked; (b) black drivers are given traffic tickets when white drivers are given warnings; (c) black defendants in court are given prison terms when white defendants on the same crimes are given probation.  This is compounded by discrimination by employers based on what appears to be a black name.  

See Part 2.

Comment: In environmental terms, it is a huge mistake to extract and burn any fossil fuel, including methane. It is being done in many states because widespread fracking caused a glut of cheap methane. A carbon tax, such as the one described in this article, would help to address this.

New nuclear plants are problematic in the US. They are extraordinarily expensive and take so many years to permit, design, and build that they are not proving to be much help in climate terms. Also, the electricity they produce is too expensive for them to be economically viable.

Photovoltaic cells, by far the most common type of solar panel, use only common earth elements. Some thin-film solar cells use rare earth elements which are recycled at end of life.  There are some newer designs of thin-film solar, including some from research at Binghamton (NY) University, that do not use any rare earth elements, so the problem of the lifecycle of rare-earth elements should diminish in the future.

Comment: I agree that hand-texting should be illegal and subject to normal traffic citation but according, to the reliably documented FARS data reported by NHTSA, fatal crashes associated with distracted driving involving electronic devices such as cell phones are about 3% (12% of 25% due to distraction) of total fatalities. Fatalities involving an intoxicated driver are ten times greater (31%).  These data do not differentiate between hand-texting and hand-held or hands-free talking. I would guess the crashes almost entirely involve hand-texting, since phone conversations differ little from conversations with passengers that account for 1.25% (5% of 25%  due to distraction) of recorded fatal crashes.

I find no data that might justify prohibition of hands-free or even hand-held talking on a cell phone. I'm sure hand-texting increases crash risk, and ironically, even trying to hide the phone from police while talking might do so.

Comment: Then why are the hotels also paying property taxes? I have no problem with taxes per se. But they shouldn't be taken for granted "just because we've always had them". Situations and technologies change, what was appropriate then might not be now. There may be a more efficient or less-intrusive, less expensive way to achieve the same goals. Hell, even those goals may no longer exist in the same way.

Every few years pretty much every law, especially tax laws, should be dragged out into the sunlight and, within the context of the entire tax package (in this case) examined for redundancys and actual effectiveness at addressing the specific goals they were intended to address. Any laws, particularly taxes and criminal laws, that are redundant, ineffective, or counter-productive, should be immediately repealed.

By my druthers any law or tax should have a 5 or 10 year sunset provision built in, requiring a specific legislative act with required full debate process, to be reenacted.

Comment: It's true, the math works out that on average public transit pollutes more per passenger mile than private automobiles. Think about it: an 18-ton bus has to accelerate and stop to pick up and drop off each and every passenger, and often carries only a handful of passengers during off-peak hours.

It's also works out that bicycling is also worst for the environment! It takes far more resources to produce food calories than other fuels... for example, raising cattle uses 15,000 liters of fresh water per kilogram of beef produced, and produces 27 kilograms of CO2 for each kilogram of beef. When all the math is done, converting calories of food intake to miles cycled, and assuming a typical diet of foods, cycling is worst than driving!

However, there are other reasons to cycle and use buses, such as health, cost, congestion, etc.

Comment: have you ever taught and graded a lecture with hundreds of students while working sixty hours a week on a federally funded research project?  He was being paid entirely by the Federal government to do the research, and UAA was basically getting a class taught for free.  Here's how research works:  you get hired by UAA as a research professor.  they don't pay you at all.  you have to go out and get a grant from an organization like the National Science Foundation.  UAA takes the entirety of that grant into their coffers, and pays you a stipend from it, as well as all of your research costs.  the rest of the money (approximately 58%) gets taken by the university for "Facilities and Administrative costs".  He is effectively paying the university to employ him.  On top of that, the NSF expects a product in return for all of that grant money.  That peer reviewed paper is his sole contractual obligation.  the people who actually pay him have no lecture requirement.

Comment: There are several layers of law involved when it comes to land use. Starting from the top, federal law. Indian, or native Hawaiian, land is regulated by federal law. State law. Some country and city land use is regulated by state law, which sometimes overlaps with local law. Local law is C&C of Honolulu. Lowest down the ladder is neighborhood law, in this case, Neighborhood Board "law" - which is really a patchwork of what a person living in the neighborhood wants and does not want. The north shore doesn't want any native property use because that brings in federal law and crimes are not permissible under federal law the same way they are permissible under local law levels due to who you know and what strings you can pull. If this was native land use, no one would be able to control it except the feds.

Comment: The government of Canada is myopic as always. When NAFTA was originally negotiated, the USA was structured as an importer of oil. Canada continues to be an importer of USA services, resulting in a virtually balance free trade balance. The USA has now structured itself as an EXPORTER of crude oil, thereby not needing Canadian oil if it chooses, and even competing with Canada on a global basis. Canada will still need to importer badly needed USA services, hence the danger of moving forward with NAFTA as structured. Canada will have a massive negative import/export relationship with the USA, a very bad deal for Canada`s economic future. Continuing the NAFTA deal even slightly modified will be massively destructive to our country. Move on and deal with the rest of the world with free-trade agreements, not the USA. The gravy train is over for Canada!

Comment: Oregon's mail-in ballots have raised voter turnout.  Additionally, the system provides a "hard copy" of ballots.  If, in fact, we want people, and by that I mean all eligible citizens, to vote, a mail-in system is considerably preferable to having polling places.  It allows voters to sit down around the kitchen or dining table, read the voter guide, talk with family and make an informed decision.  It completely eliminated the issue of "voter suppression" using limited hours, inconvenient locales, limited voting machines, intimidation at the polling place and other tactics which the right-wing has employed to suppress voting.  You can depend on the right-wingers opposing systems like "motor-voter" which make it easier to register to vote and mail-in ballots which make it easier to vote.  There is NO evidence of significant voter fraud.  There is ample evidence of voter suppression.  Gary Crum

Comment: The Legislature has adopted a goal of 22,500 new affordable rental units by 2026.  According to HUD guidelines (people shouldn’t spend more than 30% of their income on housing) the average individual renter in Hawaii earns enough to afford about $700 a month on rent.  That’s enough to cover the cost to build a $300,000 unit.  The problem is that the average rental unit in Hawaii costs about $400,000 to build (averaged-out over all unit sizes).  So there’s a $100,000 per unit gap – which is why private developers have largely steered clear of building affordable rentals for the last 25 years.  So to meet the state goal we will need subsidies totaling $2.25 billion.  Sounds like a huge number.  But if we were to finance the investment through general obligation bonds at today’s rates and amortize the cost over 40 years -we assume the housing would last that long, right?- the cost would be about $100 million a year.

Comment: (ONE)

YES!! YES!!

I came across a reply by CaeLew the other day to a comment something like "A central tenet of Catholicism is that doctrine does not change."  She profoundly rebutted "A central tenet of the universe is that everything evolves." 

In a nutshell that captures what I believe the Holy Spirit has been screaming at us for the last couple of hundred years, and most dramatically since the discovery of the big bang one hundred years ago. Virtually all previous human thought, and most emphatically all previous theology, assumed the exact opposite--a stable universe and an even more stable arena in which humans, regardless when they live, work out what is true.

Ultimately, I believe we must accept that revelation itself is not only ONGOING (in the minimalist sense that the Holy Spirit continues to attempt to influence us, although profoundly hampered by freedom to not listen), but actually EVOLVES (what she says changes over time, adjusting to our capacity to understand).

Comment: Forget the short term - in the short term there is going to be pain. Lumber, cars, perhaps dairy, all of those areas are in Trump's crosshairs and he has now fired the first shot.

So, in the interim we pay the price for not widening our customer base.

Basically we will pay the price for not asking a fundamental question: In the long term, in a world of 9 billion (in 2050) and then 12 billion (in 2100), what does Canada have that the world will need and cannot easily obtain elsewhere.

We know the answer, we just don't like it. It makes us out as "hewers of wood, drawers of water".

So what?

We have resources. Land, Water.  Develop them, now. Open up the North. Open up Ontario's Ring of Fire.

The pipeline obstructionism of the past decade has exposed the soft underbelly of Canada: we want to pretend we're more than resources, the rest of the world views us, economically, only as a resource state.

Make up your mind folks, the train for the 22nd century is approaching the station.

Comment: Thank you, HM, for what may well have been an unintended consequence of exposing the essence of this forum's inveterate moralist. Much like a young boy who mimics the batting stance and swing of his favorite ballplayer, our rural rube fancies himself a latter-day Mencken, betrayed by his aping of the satirist's style, his cadences, even his absent-minded sprinkling of "indeed" and phrases like "ipso facto." And Mencken, as everyone knows, was fascinated by Nietzsche. Yes, it all makes sense now. Just as that young boy's dream never escaped the sandlot, the Mencken worshipper's limits are circumscribed by carefully cataloged op-ed filler masquerading as reason and pith.

A side note: Check out "Men versus the Man: A Correspondence between Robert Rives La Monte, Socialist, and H.L. Mencken, Individualist [1910]," available online, and pages 116-117 for Mencken's views on . . . well, you'll see.. It makes Trump's stump rhetoric sound like Gandhi.

Comment: As the owner of a small software company for almost 30 years, I agree with the conclusion but not how it was derived.  Beyond determining 'how to innovate' we need to know 'what to innovate'.  The conception that works for me is that Silicon Valley is the central hub of the cyber-universe, but that hub works in concert with many satellites.  It's essential that we have knowledge migration, shared labour pools, and open commerce and trade with Silicon Valley in order to succeed.  The opening for a Canadian hub is in the area of applications of technology, more than developing core technology.  We don't have the capital or labour pool to build the next killer app.  Blackberry was the exception, but ultimately could not compete with the giant Apple.  That being said, there are many challenges and obstacles that impede our potential success, but I'm out of room.

Comment: I agree that people are not very aware of basic science or the scientific process.  You seem to have made some efforts to understand but I think you need to go a bit deeper.  Solar radiation has been measured for 40 years and is more or less constant.  (+- 0.5 watts at 1,360 watts per square meter)  Carbon dioxide absorbs outgoing radiation quite readily and is a major contributer to the greenhouse gas effect that warms our planet and makes it habitable.  Without greenhouse gases the surface temperature would be about -18C on average, but with them it's about 15C on average.   It's true that in past warming events the temperature increased and then CO2 increased.  However this is the first time we know of where CO2 has increased before temperature increased.  (CO2 increased from 280 ppm about 150 years ago to 400 ppm today.  We are just now beginning to see the effect on temperature.  Most scientists would agree that CO2 is has a far greater effect today on global warming than the sun.

Comment: The decision is no surprise. Parliament has legal supremacy. The referendum is a political expression that cannot bind the hands of Parliament. This is why referenda in Westminster democracies are invariably a terrible idea, as David Cameron learned. When he lost, the right thing to do would have been to dissolve parliament and call an election. The coward didn't do that.

The UK (and Canada) is a representative democracy. When we vote, we delegate the authority to govern to Parliamentarians. That's why voting matters. Parliamentarians are not robots that poll the electorate to decide what to do at any given moment. They have every right, even an obligation, to exercise their own judgement. There is absolutely no legal requirement that they implement policy and law on the basis of the popularity at any given moment in time. There might be political consequences for implementing unpopular policy, but that's another matter.

Comment: This is consistently being mischaracterized as an example of overbooking, when it is actually a matter of the airline putting its own interests ahead of that of passengers. United management needed to get a flight crew across the country quickly, and didn't see any problem with bumping paying customers who were already boarded, and, in the end, relying on force to accomplish that goal. How much was it worth to United, financially, to get that crew to its destination? The airline should have been willing to pay that price by bidding up the cost of seats on that flight until passengers volunteered (really volunteered, as opposed to being dragged from the plane) to leave. Essentially, in the end, United resorted to thuggery--and violated regulations on denying passage to passengers who are already boarded--in order to save a few dollars. Putting profit ahead of the health and welfare of passengers is the real problem here, not overbooking.

Comment: So, if a skeptical friend hits you with the "saturation argument" against global warming, here’s all you need to say: (a) You’d still get an increase in greenhouse warming even if the atmosphere were saturated, because it’s the absorption in the thin upper atmosphere (which is unsaturated) that counts (b) It’s not even true that the atmosphere is actually saturated with respect to absorption by CO2, (c) Water vapor doesn’t overwhelm the effects of CO2 because there’s little water vapor in the high, cold regions from which infrared escapes, and at the low pressures there water vapor absorption is like a leaky sieve, which would let a lot more radiation through were it not for CO2, and (d) These issues were satisfactorily addressed by physicists 50 years ago, and the necessary physics is included in all climate models.

http://www.realclimate.org/index.php/archives/2007/06/a-saturated-gassy-argument

Comment: "Absent a court pronouncement on the matter, the interpretation of the relationship between the statutes placed upon them by the administrative agency charged with their enforcement has the force and effect of law."

What this means is that the agency in charge of managing the PF has primary jurisdiction to interpret the statutes, and their interpretation has the force and effect of law.

"The doctrine of primary jurisdiction does not necessarily allocate power between courts and agencies, for it governs only the question whether court or agency will initially decide a particular issue, not the question whether court or agency will finally decide the issue. Even if the agency is held to have primary jurisdiction with respect to an issue, a court may still set aside or modify what the agency has done, in accordance with the law governing the scope of review." K. Davis, Administrative Law Treatise SS 19.01, at 3 (1958).

Walker has no play ... The ball is in the PF agency's hands.

Comment: There is a darker side to home schooling, and that is the minimal followup. I have seen parents withdraw their child from school in third grade, saying they will be home schooling her. Several years later the girl returns to school - at the third grade reading level.

When I was a school nurse I was legally required to make reports of suspected abuse or neglect. Parents were never told who made the report, but they figured out (correctly most times) that it was the school. So they withdrew their children to avoid further scrutiny. 

I believe home schooling is wonderful with competent parents. But there should be mandatory accountability. As a society we all benefit from an educated populace, but no one is verifying to see if home schooled kids are really being educated, or if they are safe (particularly when reports of suspected abuse have been filed). Tax money supports home schooling, so we the public should know if it is put to good use.

Comment: Chuck's best work was done nearly 60 years ago, but I can't help feeling a little sad anyhow.  He was already an oldie when I was a youngster, but I grew up on his music.  School Days had as much meaning to me in 77 as Anarchy in the UK or Janie Jones......and as much rebellion.

It's funny, but I was talking to a millenial a couple of weeks ago who said he'd never heard Chuck Berry.  I told him if he'd heard the Stones, he'd heard Chuck.

I think if it hadn't been for the witch hunt that clobbered him and Jerry Lee Lewis, watered down Elvis, and let aberrations like Pat Boone hit the charts, he would have had many more good songs left in him. 

The establishment wouldn't let unfettered rock continue, and it wasn't until the garage rock of bands like the Trashmen and the proto punk of the Stooges or MC5 that we saw that kind of energy again.

RIP, Chuck, we won't ever see your like again.

Comment: Big difference to your example is that smoking has direct consequences to those people. The changes in regulations being imposed (versus the old regulations) don't improve public safety at all. 

It's almost like saying we already have the don't smoke within 7 meters of a door, etc as you said, but then saying "We've decided that the existing smoking laws aren't enough, since there is a slight chance that a cigarette smoked within 10 km of any trees might result in a forest fire, so it's now illegal with penalty of a fine to smoke within 10 km of any tree". 

While such a ruling is vaguely based in fact (heavily stretched etc) it is overly broad, restrictive, and gains no real safety benefit for the public, at the expense of a massive inconvenience to those who it regulates. 

(note: I'm not a smoker, and am in favor of stricter smoking regulation, but it's a good example to draw a parallel with).

Comment: I agree, but the question is whether the love of God is the source or the goal of each and every action. The creation and incarnation happened. The love of God has been displayed and given irrevocably. This is our faith.  The question is whether we believe strong enough to act accordingly in our relationships with one another (and with the whole world), or not.  If we can, we will discover God in the face of the other that makes me I, in everything we do. This is what Ignatius of Loyola describes as "contemplation in action". 

In other words, when I am changing a baby, or looking after a sick, or building a bridge, I am not thinking about the mysteries of God. I am intently focused on what I am doing. But, if I do what I do by being motivated by the love of God, I will discover God in everything I do. This is the greatest glorification of God (I do not 'give" or 'provide' glory to God, I recognise God's glory.

Comment: I believe that our roads can accommodate 40,000 cars an hour with very little slowdown.  The problem is you have a population with a varied amount of driving skills (or in some cases lack thereof) and most slowdown and accidents are caused by human error or the inability to judge merging onto and off of the freeway.  If all of the cars on the road were autonomous, traffic would move along quite nicely because cars would be able to automatically merge onto and off of the freeway with very little slowdowns since it would be done in an orderly and efficient manner and at close to speed limit depending on volume.  Any stalled cars would automatically have cars behind them automatically merge into other lanes with very minor slowdowns to get around the stalled cars.  This will all happen in the next 10-20 years and due to mass production efficiencies, these innovations will appear on all car types (not just luxury cars).

Comment: I've ridden this roller coaster for over 40 years. When mineral prices are up, investors invest. When prices are down, they pull their money and write off the loss. They spend the money trying to develop a property when the mineral prices are up, When in fact they should have done that while the prices are down so they would be poised to produce when prices go up. Then when the market tanks before they can produce, Their money is lost as well as their stomach for trying again. It's and endless cycle of buying high and selling low. Echo Bay pulled out of the AJ when gold was $265 an ounce. They cited the need for prices to be at least $350 per ounce to start to make a profit. They weren't gone long before gold jumped to $1,900/oz and still holding around $1,200. They could have been making bank today, even with that low grade ore. Now CBJ wants to start it up again to produce revenue. Again, buying high. Risky business? Yes. But not as risky as starting up on the backside of the apex.

Comment: I get not liking the alternatives too much, but how do you reach the conclusion that the economy is running well here? But if you look at this "success" in any sort of detail, it sure doesn't look like a win if your goal is to build a sustainable economy that will prosper in the future. The economy is very de-diversified. The Lower Mainland has a growing net loss of people under the age of 45, with 60%+ people reporting a desire to leave the region (which comprises over half the province's population). Business and government leaders in Vancouver, and now Victoria are reporting significant issues attracting and retaining talent. These sorts of problems are not the byproducts of a well run economy. They are what happens when you burn the future to shine today.

Comment: I agree in part.   Unfortunately,there are people in my industry who I would not trust with the loose change in my pocket.   They are unethical and are more interested in how the client interaction benefits them rather than the person(s) sitting across from them seeking guidance and advice.    These are the people who give career advisers a bad name.    I have said for decades that this is perhaps the most loosely regulated professional industry in Canada.     For example, a dish washer with zero experience in the financial market can get sponsored by an investment firm, write the IFC exam (2 hours) and immediately advertise himself as an investment advisor.    I see client statements on virtually a daily basis where the client has been exposed to unnecessary volatility and risk in pursuit of a mythical investment return that borders on fantasy.    Crackdown and criminal prosecution of these charlatans is overdue......the client deserves better.

A Very Concerned Senior.

Comment: "So home appreciation at 3% equates to ~5-6% earned on investments. Financially, these don't seem far apart"  Oh but it is.  A basket of stocks typically return 8-10% over the long run before tax so let's say it's 5-6% annual return after tax depending on your tax bracket.  Canadian banks typically return 12-15% annually so that would be 7-9% after tax.  Both of these would double the appreciation on a primary residence, meaning that over 25-30 years of compounding, the home owner loses big time.  I do agree that it's a lifestyle choice but if it's strictly a financial choice, renting wins in the current market and have been winning in the past 3-5 years.

Comment: When I was growing up 60 or 70 years ago, nobody had health insurance ... didn't need it because medical care was inexpensive. (I'm not even sure there was such a thing as insurance back then.) You could go to the ER and have a cut stitched or a broken bone set and cast and it cost at most about $50.
I went to college in 1960 and medical care for students was covered by the university at the campus hospital. Then I was in the Navy until 1970, and, of course, the base hospitals took care of us including two babies we had on base.
Then when I got out of the Navy, insurance companies came on the scene and healthcare costs skyrocketed, as did insurance premiums. I had to get insurance for my family, and in just the first year it cost more for insurance premiums than what it had cost for medical services in the entire previous 28 years of my life.
Isn't it obvious that the insurance industry is the culprit here? They're the middlemen who devour the money. We need to get them out of the way.

Comment: Your characterization of all journalists and journalism with the blanket term "the media" is a form of newspeak--propaganda, in this case, of the alt-right variety. Journalists are people and there is variety in their approaches to gathering and covering what is newsworthy. It's one thing to criticize journalists and outlets for corporate bias, it's another to lump all forms of journalism and types of journalists under the now deprecatory term "the media."

Comment: I think the article misses a point about park sweeps. No one thinks this will "solve" homelessness. The public does not care. They simply want these people out of the parks. 
I'm all for an intensive effort to truly move the homeless to stable housing, but such an effort has to be paired with a reclaiming of PUBLIC space from being monopolized by a narrow demographic. 
And let's acknowledge that the homeless usually present with mental illness, substance abuse, or both. Who wants that in a neighbor? We are doing all involved a disservice to ignore the reality. 
Spend the money to solve the problem (rehab, mental health counseling, steady housing, etc.) but by all means sweep these people out of our parks and libraries. To do otherwise undermines any public support for anything homeless.

Comment: I'm not a big fan of "hate," and, I agree, much of the turmoil and violence of our world is a manifestation of that hatred.  It's possible to focus on a specific topic, but sometimes it's more interesting to look at the "big questions".  For example, from where does all the hatred in today's world come?  Why do we see the turmoil and warfare which continues to characterize the world?  Why do we see racial and ethnic cleansing?  Why do we see, figurative, and often literal, warfare between religions? Why must we be as politically and philosophically polarized in our country as we are today?  I could go on for pages asking why, why, why.. I agree, we somehow need to sit down, find those things we actually agree on and from that starting point try to resolve our differences on those other issues.  Until we're willing to do that, we'll see more and more results of that "hatred" you mention.  Thanks for your considered comments.   Gary Crum

Comment: I tried it for a few minutes but quickly lost patience. Mostly what I learned from the biofeedback experience was to slow down my breathing. I use that sometimes to try to get to sleep and sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't. I think some of us are born with highly reactive nervous systems, which are also not well-suited to meditation practices, including progressive relaxation. Our minds and bodies don't "sit still" that long. 

I liked the biofeedback approach because it was mechanical: all I had to do was breathe and look at the moving chart on the computer screen. In did produce results for quite a while and I think in time would have trained me to do it without the computer. Wasn't able to do it long enough.

I would like to find a way to do that on my home computer. So far I haven't found an affordable way to get the necessary sensors and software. Amazon sells some simple biofeedback gadgets but customer comments do not inspire confidence.

Comment: I get what you're saying, but I see things differently. We place restrictions on participation in all kinds of markets here (including employment). I think there is room for some constructive regulation. 

I do think the 1% vacancy rate is also very attributable in part to how supply is being used, given that some speculatively acquired places are sitting empty or being used for things like AirBnB (i.e. not for rent). The growth rate in the Lower Mainland right now is actually LOWER than it was when real estate prices and rents were relatively flat 10 and 20 years ago. If you look at pop. growth and housing completion data from the last few years here and consider the average household size, you get a sense that more than enough supply is being built. 

Also, look at the links above. It's not the opposite: the kids ARE leaving (and more are considering it). And you just need to walk the streets in the many ghost neighborhoods here to know "booming" is not a great descriptor.

Comment: Except none of them are near the population centers or the logistics handling capacity needed.

Anchorage is the base of the railroad, with the railyard just off the port and its cargo handling capacity as well as routing for cargo laden trains. Further east are yards for any number of cargo companies including TOTE and Carlile Transport which move cargo throughout the south-central region (and further).
Relocating to Whittier, Valdez or Seward would require a massive realignment of logistics capacity. Additionally, with the limited redundancies of a single rail line/road (often co-located) in and out of those towns, an earthquake or even large avalanche (as we see frequently) could shut down vital supplies to and from the #1 and #2 population centers in the state for days. It would create a major issue for Anchorage and Mat-Su, never-mind further north communities like Fairbanks.

Comment: The English translation of Spiritus Sanctus in my young days was "Holy Ghost" and had been for centuries. I would say it is unfashionable rather than archaic.
Having used the word every time one made the sign of the Cross for over thirty years, it is hard to get out of the habit also the single syllable 'ghost' is easier to say and more rhythmic than the two syllable 'spirit' when saying 'In the name of the Father ...' and the 'Glory be ...'
The Latin hymns Veni Creator and Veni Sancte Spiritus are rendered in English as 'Come Holy Ghost'.
In Shakespeare's day confessors were known as 'ghostly fathers'.
Another reason for sticking with it is that for some reason it irks progressives, possibly because it reminds them that there actually was a Church before Vatican II.  ;-)
No one I knew, child or adult was ever confused by it.

Comment: The problem is that there is no agreement or norm established in laws as to who is or is not capable of legal consent based solely on age. In many US states and almost all Western nations, a 16-year-old is allowed to consent and is treated as being old enough to make those decisions. We can raise our eyebrows but there is no crime. If they had been in Vancouver, Washington and had sex - no consent issue, no crime. Bad judgment, yes, but no crime.

The fact that it is a crime in Oregon results from a number admittedly picked from the sky by an advisory commission to the 1971 legislature. It doesn't result from any kind of evaluation of human development.

I would have no issue with using 18 as a baseline if the 16-year-old's actual mental, emotional and physical capacity could be used as a defense, but in Oregon it can't. The law as written is a cheap way out of a complex set of issues.

Comment: I remember the Ghomeshi case quite well and it wouldn't be fair to say he was innocent of any wrongdoing. He was found not guilty at the first trial, and prior to the second trial the complainant agreed to forgo the proceedings if Ghomeshi would issue a formal apology for his behavior, which he did. 

In the case before us now, Justice Camp was not alleged to have committed an offence. He simply didn't do his job the way it needed to be done. He freely and openly admits his errors in thinking concerning sexual assault law and has taken concrete steps to rectify the deficiency.

Despite those striking differences, it's interesting to note that the outcome for both Ghomeshi and Camp are quite similar. Both have been publicly vilified and their careers destroyed. I submit that the similarity in outcome is evidence that the public and its institutions fail to keep a balanced perspective when allegations of male-on-female sexism are made.

Comment: So, at most conclaves, the Rome-based cardinals have formed a bloc of votes prior to the arrival of other electors, and have virtually eliminated certain candidates they considered unacceptable. Sometimes they've been surprised, such as the election of Pope John and, to a certain extent, that of Pope Francis. The former was clearly able to get things done. The latter -- we'll see.

In other words, Francis can make cardinals out of soft water taffy if he likes. The question is whether his appointees can elect someone who can cut through Vatican politics better than he has. At the moment, the oddsmakers list as the favorites to replace Francis: Tagle (6-1), Scola (7-1), Turkson (7-1), and Oellet (7-1)., with some oddsmakers giving these men even longer odds.

The addition of electors from lesser-known dioceses probably won't affect the odds, although they may be able to influence the outcome.

Comment: This has to be one of the dumbest decisions in many years by a Judge of the Court of Queen’s Bench. Non-Catholics may attend because they want to attend the same school as their Catholic friends, or students might choose because of the courses offered. Others may attend because of the close proximity to where they live. We can only hope that the decision is appealed and successfully overturned.

Now, people's needs. expectations, and life span have increased almost exponentially. and by the time the baby boomers all retire, there is no way that the workers will be able to support them/us in the style to which we've become accustomed. 
At the same time, some have become enamoured of the idea that they're special and shouldn't pay tax, and there are aggressive tax planners who make a living trying to make it so.
Our tax system needs to change.  This is one small start.

Comment: There is a MUCH less complicated parallel here than CETA, it is called the European Free Trade Association.

The EFTA is a collection of 4 non-EU countries in Europe (Norway, Switzerland, Lichtenstein and Iceland) that have collaborated to negotiate free trade deals.  They have free trade with Europe and yes, Canada (just came into effect in 2009), among others.  Unlike the EU though they do not share a currency (not that the UK ever did) or many of the other EU policies.

I don't know that it is necessarily possible for the UK to straight-up join the EFTA and adopt their free trade deals, but it isn't out of the realm of possibilities and certainly the UK could adopt something similar themselves.

Comment: When NK launches missiles, it's always over the "Korean peninsula", which invariably means NK.

When we conduct air missions in response, it's always over the "Korean peninsula", which invariably means SK.

So they use the exact same term in diametrically opposed ways, which renders it meaningless and useless -- except for propaganda purposes.

It serves those nicely, because in the first case it leaves the impression that just perhaps those lousy NKs fired a missile that transited SK airspace.  Can't tolerate that!  And in the second, that perhaps the bold US and its noble ally SK sent an air sortie into NK airspace.  Ooh, that'll teach 'em!  

But in neither case is that ever what happened, so the term "Korean peninsula" has become a meaningless waste of letters.

Comment: In the pits that capture manure under factory-scale hog farms, a gray, bubbly substance began appearing at the surface of the fecal soup. 

The problem is menacing: 

As manure breaks down, it emits toxic gases like hydrogen sulfide and flammable ones like methane, and trapping these noxious fumes under a layer of foam can lead to sudden, disastrous releases and even explosions. 

According to a 2012 report from the University of Minnesota, by September 2011, the foam had “caused about a half-dozen explosions in the upper Midwest…one explosion destroyed a barn on a farm in northern Iowa, killing 1,500 pigs and severely burning the worker involved.”

Yet most of the right disagrees with a carbon tax, and the Liberals want both the carbon tax and expensive intervention in the market.  The environmental activist left seems to want their cake and eat it too - carbon tax but also related government handouts and jobs to serve themselves.   

We'll see what happens in the CPC leadership vote tomorrow; I am afraid Chong is ahead of his time on this one.  The choice in 2019 will be no carbon tax at all, or a very expensive and wasteful emissions plan.

Comment: Be aware this issue is froth with confusion, complexity and misinformation. If you think Indian status is complicated on mainland Canada, it is more so on the Island of Newfoundland. When NL joined Canada it was supposed Island Mi'kmaq would fall under the Indian Act. Turns out the feds were already planning to wean Canada's aboriginals off government subsidies and so St. Laurent denied federal responsibility. NL had neither the wherewithal nor inclination to fill in for the feds and so NL's innu languished in no-man's land for decades. The province was also convinced its Mi'kmaq were not aboriginal, at least not to NL - that their arrival post-dated the European presence there (and hence with no stronger land claim than any other settler). The criteria for Qalipu status is more narrow than the national model; they must have a current and substantial connection to native communities on the Island. And that, it turns out, accounts for the vast majority of the rejections. 

Clear as mud?

Comment: Nope....they're FCS.  Big Sky Conference football teams participate in the FCS playoffs, not the FBS bowls.  FBS and FCS schools are all NCAA Division I for the other sports (the Big Sky basketball tournament champion does, for instance, go to the NCAA Division I Tournament...usually as a #13-#16 seed).

In football, Eastern Washington, North Dakota, Cal Poly, and Weber State represented the Big Sky in the 2016 FCS Playoffs, with Eastern Washington losing to Youngstown State in the semifinals.

Scholarships numbers are the difference.
NCAA FBS- 85 max.
NCAA FCS- 65 max.
NCAA Division II- Equivalent of up to 36 (can be partials between more than one athlete, for total up to 36).
NCAA Division III- No athletic scholarships.

Comment: I am glad that I have lived thru this period of Alaskan history and witnessed the sudden growth of communications in bush Alaska--for many years we had to order from catalogs-the best that we could  afford to receive am radio signals from FAIRBANKS and ANCHORAGE  stations-KFQD-KFAR-KFRB-KENI--were some,. and then the one village phone came and things blossomed from there-to where we are really connected--radio--tv--internet and any and all forms of communications--this improved the whole quality of life for all of us -in bush Alaska -ALSO since 1962-thru my enlistment/draft into theARMY I attended electronics schools in Los Angeles--Fairbanks and finally US ARMY signal schools in New Jersey and Georgia-so I basically knew what was in the works--when I settled in GOLOVIN/home I was able to jury-rig antennas to recieve short-wave stations-worldwide-and also A-M stations when weather co-operated--opened up the world for me.....I loved it all.....

But I also believe that the poor will benefit greatly from the additional support from more wealthy consumers, from the corporations, and from the money leveraged from the federal government. Oregon Health Plan benefits alone are life-changing--way beyond any percentage of the 2.5% tax on the less than 1% of companies registered to do business in Oregon they end up paying. Add to that support for public schools and for senior services and you have a vast advantage for the poor in Measure 97.

St Josemaria Escriva:

Comment: I understand your reaction and I feel your pain.  I was you in 1987 - no chance we could really afford what was on offer.   30 years later I have to respectfully inform you that this is just the way it is.  I've lived through multiple cycles:  1987, the 1989 crash, NDP recession of the 90's and recovery, and 2007/2008 great recession spillover. 

Bottom line is that Toronto is NOT just any other city.  It's unique in Canada.  The prices here are what they are due to a unique mix of factors and pressures based on a real economy and desire for people to live here.  Similar types of factors that drive similar types of prices in New York, London, San Francisco, high-end Chicago and LA.   Like those places, prices will certainly ebb and flow with government regulation changes, the overall economy, inflation, employment, interest rates and great recessions.  However, over time, the desire to live in a place (that is, actual supply and demand) is the only factor driving the housing market.

Comment: Staying in the Paris Accord, which was a treaty not an "agreement", wouldn't have changed the reality of climate change either. But what will change is our potential response to the inevitable.

The Accords REQUIRE every person of a member country submit to provisions of the document, which for the US meant an economy-killing rollback of the use of fossil fuels with no VIABLE replacement energy. How does a country crippled by its own stupidity respond to a natural cycle that requires adaption because control is impossible? Had we stayed with the Accords, developing nations would have used US funding to adapt while we would have been starving in the dark and cold. Now we can hope to adapt and survive.

Comment: Who knows? I know exactly how I'd react, because I've been in a car vs. pedestrian accident. It was over 20 years ago. It never entered my mind once to do anything other than call 911 and try to help the pedestrian. I was bleeding from the head, sobbing, injured and terrified, but I can't fathom making any other choice than running to him and getting help as fast as possible.  

Even if I did something wrong (which I didn't) I would never in a million years pull an injured man off my car and leave him alone at the scene. I was only going 25mph, I came up over the crest of a hill and he was in the middle of my lane; nothing I could do. I could smell Scotch on him, I remember thinking, "I hope it numbs his pain," not, "I should get outta here and hide my car."
